Title: Built environmental correlates of older adults' total physical activity and walking: a systematic review and meta-analysis
Authors: David W Barnett, Anthony Barnett, Andrea Nathan, Jelle Van Cauwenberg, Ester Cerin
Supporting quotes for "Review type":
- "systematic review and meta-analysis"
  - "This systematic review and meta-analysis was registered in PROSPERO (Registration no. CRD42016051227 [38]) in November 2016."
  - "Due to the large range of different environmental and PA measures reported in the selected articles, it was not possible to conduct a 'traditional' meta-analysis involving the estimation of pooled effect sizes and their 95% confidence intervals. Hence, to quantitatively synthesise the findings, a meta-analytic approach was applied to define conservative estimates of p-values for each examined combination of environmental attribute and PA outcome [27]."
  - "to quantitatively synthesise the findings, a meta-analytic approach was applied to define conservative estimates of p-values for each examined combination of environmental attribute and PA outcome [27]."
Reasoning for "Review type":
The paper states that it is a "systematic review and meta-analysis":
"This systematic review and meta-analysis was registered in PROSPERO (Registration no. CRD42016051227 [38]) in November 2016."
"To quantitatively synthesise the findings, a meta-analytic approach was applied to define conservative estimates of p-values for each examined combination of environmental attribute and PA outcome [27]."
"Due to the large range of different environmental and PA measures reported in the selected articles, it was not possible to conduct a 'traditional' meta-analysis involving the estimation of pooled effect sizes and their 95% confidence intervals. Hence, to quantitatively synthesise the findings, a meta-analytic approach was applied to define conservative estimates of p-values for each examined combination of environmental attribute and PA outcome [27]."
The paper clearly states that it is a systematic review and meta-analysis, as it registered the review in PROSPERO and applied a meta-analytic approach to synthesize the findings.

Title: Economic analysis of the health impacts of housing improvement studies: a systematic review
Authors: Elisabeth Fenwick, Catriona Macdonald, Hilary Thomson
Venue: Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health
Supporting quotes for "Review type":
- "All housing intervention studies and their associated papers included in the 2009 systematic review of the health impacts of housing improvement 14 were examined for reports of costs and economic analyses."
  - "This paper presents the results of this review, providing details of the cost and economic analyses reported alongside housing intervention studies and accompanying health impacts."
  - "A separate search for economic studies was not undertaken but economic studies which included health outcomes following housing improvement would have been identified in the broad search."
Reasoning for "Review type":
The paper states that it is a "systematic review of the economic analysis of the health impacts of housing improvement studies":
"This paper presents the results of this review, providing details of the cost and economic analyses reported alongside housing intervention studies and accompanying health impacts."
"All housing intervention studies and their associated papers included in the 2009 systematic review of the health impacts of housing improvement 14 were examined for reports of costs and economic analyses."
The paper also mentions that a separate search for economic studies was not undertaken, but economic studies which included health outcomes following housing improvement would have been identified in the broad search:
"A separate search for economic studies was not undertaken but economic studies which included health outcomes following housing improvement would have been identified in the broad search."
Based on this, the review type is a systematic review, as the authors systematically reviewed the existing literature on the health impacts of housing improvement studies that also reported cost and economic analyses.

Title: Impacts of heat waves and corresponding measures: a review

  - "The aim of this research is to present a critical review of impacts of heat waves and corresponding mechanisms."
  - "This paper reports on a critical literature review which covers the following main aspects: (1) the definition of heat waves; (2) the impacts of heat waves on health, ecosystems and the built environment;

The paper does not mention conducting a meta-analysis or meta-regression. Therefore, the review type is a systematic review.

Title: The use of climate information to estimate future mortality from high ambient temperature: A systematic literature review
Authors: Michael Sanderson, Katherine Arbuthnott, Sari Kovats, Shakoor Hajat, Pete Falloon
Supporting quotes for "Review type":
- "Papers providing projections of future heat-related mortality were critically reviewed with a focus on the use of climate model data."
  - "A meta-analysis of the results was not conducted. The locations, time periods studied and climate model data used to estimate future heat-related mortality varied considerably between the selected articles. Instead, a descriptive summary of the estimates is provided."
  - "A total of 608 articles were identified after removal of duplicate entries, of which 63 were found to contain a quantitative estimate of future mortality from hot days or heat waves."
Reasoning for "Review type":
The paper states that it is a "systematic literature review" on the use of climate information to estimate future mortality from high ambient temperature:
"Papers providing projections of future heat-related mortality were critically reviewed with a focus on the use of climate model data."
"A total of 608 articles were identified after removal of duplicate entries, of which 63 were found to contain a quantitative estimate of future mortality from hot days or heat waves."
"A meta-analysis of the results was not conducted. The locations, time periods studied and climate model data used to estimate future heat-related mortality varied considerably between the selected articles. Instead, a descriptive summary of the estimates is provided."
The paper states that it is a systematic review, but explicitly says that a meta-analysis was not conducted due to the heterogeneity of the included studies.
